ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
-CAD modelling
-Basics of Solidworks modelling
-Solidworks Finite Element Analysis
-Solidworks Flow Simulation
-Solidworks Animations/Motion Studies
-Mechanical Engineering Parts and Principles
-Some MATLAB
This class has helped me develop a collection of projects that I feel proud to put in my portfolio to demonstrate my skills. You'll learn the ins and outs of SolidWorks.
More familiarity with solidworks, using variables for dimensions, performing motion studies, and generating drawings.
I improved my skills in Solidworks SIGNIFICANTLY.
I practiced CAD skills, and learned basic analysis in solidworks
I learned Solidworks and Solidworks CFD

I had very little experience in SolidWorks before taking this class, had never made an animation, run motion analysis or FEA simulations, and now I am very confident in my ability to do so. This class helped be build a lot of useful experience in SolidWorks making projects Prof A designed, as well as let me learn other skills on individual projects without specific rubrics.
CAD
We learned the basics of Solidworks modeling/assembly/motion studies/simulation, with additional lectures on topics such as gears and cam/followers.
How to use Solidworks: modeling, motion analysis, finite element analysis, and flow simulation. Also some Matlab.
Developed a skillset for different SolidWorks techniques and tools.
A lot about SolidWorks and some MATLAB.
I learned a ton! For someone who didn't really have much knowledge about solid works, this was a great course to build my skills in the program and practice more hands on design problems.
I learned about various techniques for CADing as well as different mechanisms for engineering.
I learned how to use solidworks and make various things with it.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths
-Very comprehensive
-The assignments are super fun and really allow you to be creative
-The professor is really nice
-The ULA's are very helpful
-Covers exactly what is promised in the course description

Weaknesses
-Too much time in zoom breakout rooms
-MATLAB instruction was minimal
-Professor sometimes talks quite a bit

Strengths: We could continually turn in assignments again to get better grades, which was perfect bc the goal of the class is to develop work we're proud of and WANT to show off to others. Plenty of office hours and time to work in class to get to know our peers, which is essential but lacked in almost every one of my other zoom classes. Every level of CADer can be in this class and improve from the baseline they came in with, and your grade is not a comparison to others but a metric of your own effort and improvement.
Weaknesses: You might die from dad jokes once you notice they never stop.
Did a great job with the break out rooms for student engagement.

Strengths: great professor who gives out assignments that are very doable and I believe he increases the difficulty of assignments incrementally which makes it much less overwhelming. I have never learned so much from one semester in such a reduced stress fashion. We also had a great grad student (Cameron Lerch) who was incredibly helpful and engaging in class as well -- he helped a lot of us troubleshoot! We also had incredibly dedicated peer tutors! I also loved the "choose your own final project" idea -- gave me space to do something I was interested in!

Weaknesses: none

Strengths:
I felt some of the projects were good challenges.  I enjoyed how open ended the final project was.

Weaknesses:
For anyone with even the most slight amount of CAD experience, this class had a ridiculously small workload.  It also covered very little material.  After the first few weeks in the course, I justified continuing to take it by expecting that material would get more advanced.  It didn't.  My CAD skills are almost exactly where they were at the start of this course.  I learned to do extremely basic analysis, but that's essentially it as far as new skills go.  

The whole section of the class on projections felt like a wild divergence from the rest.  While I definitely learned some new material there, it felt largely disconnected from anything that would be useful now that drawing engineering diagrams by hand is no longer relevant.

This class should be thoroughly restructured around concrete material.  It should start with the basics of CAD, teaching best practices like how to deal with global variables and equations.  Then it should move onto advanced design techniques: the features in solidworks which are practical but complex.  After that it should be based on analysis.  This shouldn't be analyzing random parts we make, it should be problem sets where models are provided and correct answers are expected.

A core message in this class was that we should be self motivated to do most of the learning by ourselves and do as hard of projects as we can.  While I understand this sentiment, it doesn't work in reality.  Some amount of self teaching is good, but if Yale wants to give its engineers the skills necessary to thrive in the real world, actual instruction is necessary.

The majority of the evaluations will be positive.  This will be because of the extraordinarily lenient grading in the class.  I didn't come to Yale for good grades.  I came to learn.
no weaknesses.  A fun course where I learned a lot.

Strengths: gaining a lot of SolidWorks experience, building a portfolio of cool designs, learning to run Motion Analysis and FEA simulations. Additionally, this was a relatively low-stress course with a emphasis on mastery-based learning, so we were allowed to continue to work on past projects until we got to a point we were proud of and mastered all the skills. I can't think of any weaknesses, other than potentially having access to a machine shop during a non-pandemic year so we could manufacture some of the parts we created. This course was really fun.
Strengths: project based, fun

Strengths: hands-on and fun, great professor, low stress
Weaknesses: group projects were difficult to do remotely, and sometimes the mechanical terms used in class are not fully explained to the non-mechE majors

Great class, not stressful at all. A mastery based class, so you worked at your own level of expertise and could redo assignments until you mastered them. I wish there was more content during our lectures, such as how to do more complicated modeling.

Workload is very well structured to foster understanding and mastery of the concepts. The only improvement that can be made is to cover more features of SolidWorks, but this is where the breadth vs depth dichotomy comes into play. Not much should change about this class, I enjoyed it a great deal.

It is very nice to have mastery-based learning and be graded on our own progress; I think I was able to push myself without being compared to students with previous experiences. I think that some of the assignments are a lot harder than others (the MATLAB assignment was a lot).

I would say having the class online was actually a strength. Being able to follow along with my screen and even re-watch the recorded lectures if I missed something was extremely helpful. The ULAs were also great.
There are no weaknesses to this course. Any student in the class learns a lot through the assignments. There is also a lot of student collaboration which is helpful.

I wish it went more in depth about how to use various features of SolidWorks. Not just the basic CAD skills that we learn repeatedly. But I thought it was taught well, teaching us practical aspects instead of just theory, like a lot of other classes.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Overall very successfull!

The lectures were good over zoom and the zoom breakout room feature was used well (though maybe a bit too much)
The daily breakout rooms were very helpful in meeting classmates and remaining engaged.
Doc A utilized breakout rooms quite often which was great because we got to get to know different people in the class and work on our projects in smaller groups.
We're fine.

The use of both live lectures and pre-recorded tutorials for some of the projects was really useful. The pre-recorded tutorials walked us through the most straightforward parts of making components, and didn't take class time. Class time was often used for group work and asking questions to the professor and classmates. Overall it ran very well.
Recorded lectures

I really enjoyed watching the final projects. I wish we did more presentations of our assignments throughout the semester. I learned a lot from hearing what other students completed and how they overcame certain challenges in Solidworks.
I actually really liked that we had time set aside to just work in breakout groups. I ended up meeting and talking to people I never would have interacted with.

This class was probably the best structured for COVID of all the courses I've taken this year, most so because it places a large emphasis on individual exploration and mastery of the SolidWorks application.
Group projects were a bit hard to handle, but I think it worked out well.

This class being online was an advantage for sure. Even with the breakout rooms and sharing screens, collaboration was still achievable, and being able to watch the pre-recorded lectures was very helpful.
The group assignments worked quite well during COVID. It made class feel more engaging while allowing the students to interact with each other diespite not being in person.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes absolutely! Professor Adrezin is super nice and tells a lot of stories. The grading is super great because you can continue to resubmit assignments until you get 100% (or above that as there's extra credit). You learn quite a bit and is a great class for those who already know Solidworks and those who have never used it before.
YES. If you love CAD you'll love this class. Every engineering major at Yale should try to take this, because it feels like what engineering should be instead of getting lost in theory.
I would recommend this class to any mechanical engineering students with no CAD knowledge, those that have some experience should take 425.

Yes -- Doc A genuinely wants you to succeed and will be there to help you with anything. He is also incredibly funny which makes the class much more engaging. Beyond that, he structures assignments so they don't overwhelm you and the learning curve doesn't shoot straight up -- it is very incremental which makes learning Solidworks MUCH SMOOTHER.
I wouldn't recommend this course to anyone who already has some understanding of CAD and doesn't absolutely need to take it.
YES!

Absolutely! This class was fantastic and a lot of fun. We built SolidWorks portfolios, and learned skills that would make us useful in an engineering environment. I feel very confident in my SolidWorks abilities now.
Yes I would recommend. Got better at CAD and was a fun class because of the projects.
Yes! Take this course! You get out of it as much as you put into it, but even learning just the basics of CAD is so useful. The weekly assignments were fun, and the professor encourages creativity.
Yes, great for building your toolbox of marketable skills.
Yes, this class is very useful to anyone who has an interest in developing their CAD skills and learning more about useful engineering software.
Yes for engineers and/or people who just like to build cool things
YES! If you are interested in learning how to use a CAD software, this is great class to get an overarching introduction to solid works exploring multiple features.
I would HIGHLY recommend this course in order to learn how to use solidworks well.
I would recommend it to another student. It taught fundamentals of CAD in an easy-to-learn way.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None
Occasionally we had some recorded tutorials either from the professor or in the SolidWorks software.
Videos were uploaded and there were many office hours throughout the week
N/A
I loved it!
Live virtual lectures every class day, as well as some pre recorded tutorials for some projects
We could follow pre-recorded tutorials for our homework assignments. We also had a lot of time in breakout rooms to work in groups.
Recorded lectures and live virtual lectures.
We were learning Solidworks (a CAD software), so many of our classes were follow along tutorials learning new features and tools.
NA
Lectures were also recorded.
